nodes.bodyText: You should have some kind of boolean to check if you already resumed once, otherwise an exception will be thrown second time the callback is called (I assume it's possible)
Thanks for your notice, I've adapted the code a bit, hope it's fine now
You should also guard here too I guess since you can possibly get multiple failures.

From the documentation it says onFailure can be called at most one time, so I don't think another guard is needed here.

                * Will be called at most one time. It is considered a terminal event. After called,
Ah ok got it. What about the one failure and n successes? Can that happen?

The documentation says that onFailure is a terminal that means if it happens, onSuccess will never be called, however I'm not sure if we can get onSuccess prior the onFailure or not. Better to hear from the maintainers in that case.
Got it thanks for clarification! I'll leave up to to you guys who know more

onSuccess will be called several time if using the cache (one for the cache response, another for the network response for an exemple). If fetching from the network fails, there will be one onSuccess and one onFailure call.
Users needing to use cache responses should really usetoFlow instead but await() should not crash if that ever happens.
Also, I think there's no guarantee what thread the callbacks are called in so resumeIsCalled would have to be thread-safe. Maybe something like:
resumeIsCalled = AtomicBoolean()
if (!resumeIsCalled.getAndSet(true)) {
   cont.resume(response)
}

I'm not familiar with this library tbh, but reading the documentation for ApolloPrefetch says it should only be called back once so you shouldn't need this. Then again adding the check doesn't hurt. I'll let library maintainers say whether this can be called multiple times or not.
I'm not 100% sure either. I'd vote to play it safe and keep the guard there.

is there any reason to not use cont.isCancelled? There was an issue with RC but looks like it was fixed Kotlin/kotlinx.coroutines#830

+ * Suspends the [ApolloCall] until it completes and returns the value on success or throws an exception on failure.

+ * @return the response on success.
+ * @throws ApolloException on failure.
+ */

+
+  cont.invokeOnCancellation {
+    cancel()
+  }
+

This boolean was introduced to guard against calling resume multiple times to prevent an exception getting thrown for resuming with multiple values instead of one, same below.
So I'm not sure how isCancelled  would solve this particular case.
